Result.Abstract: Since mathematical models came to be applied to problems of architectural and urban form, new concepts based on predicting large-scale structure from local rules have emerged through insights originating in computation and biology. The clearest of these are computer models based on cellular automata (CA) and their recent generalization in evolutionary biology and artificial life. Here we show how such
Result.Title: From cells to cities

Result.Abstract: In urban systems modeling, there are many elaborate dynamic models based on intricate decision processes whose simulation must be based on customized software if their space–time properties are to be explored effectively. Result.Title: Modeling urban dynamics through GIS-based cellular automata

Result.Abstract: Small-scale spatial events are situations in which elements or objects vary in such a way that temporal dynamics are intrinsic to their representation and explanation. Some of the clearest examples involve local movement, from conventional traffic modeling to disaster evacuation where congestion, crowding, panic, and related safety issues are key features. We propose that such events can be simulated using
Result.Title: The discrete dynamics of small-scale spatial events: agent-based models of mobility in carnivals and street parades

Result.Abstract: New developments in computation based on cellular automata (CA), which are finding widespread application in simulating evolution, are beginning to suggest that science is not simply about the study of actual phenomena but about potential or possible phenomena. This notion is central to design but the prospect of a new science through computation which enables systematic and formal study of
Result.Title: Possible urban automata

Result.Abstract: Despite a century of effort, our understanding of how cities evolve is still woefully inadequate. Recent research, however, suggests that cities are complex systems that mainly grow from the bottom up, their size and shape following well-defined scaling laws that result from intense competition for space. An integrated theory of how cities evolve, linking urban economics and transportation behavior to
Result.Title: The Size, Scale, and Shape of Cities

Result.Abstract: There is now wide agreement that to develop effective simulationsof urban structure, urban models must be explicitly dynamic and must contain mechanisms for linking macrostructure to microbehaviour. Result.Title: Urban evolution on the desktop: simulation with the use of extended cellular automata

Result.Abstract: Geography and its study are changing in subtle and dramatic ways in the rapid transition to a digital world. Here we present a preliminary discussion of how this new geography, which we call ‘virtual geography’, might be classified. Virtual geography is not merely Cyberspace per se for it comprises many types of place and space in which the digital world
Result.Title: Virtual geography

Result.Abstract: An increasing number of models for predicting land use change in rapidly urbanizing regions are being proposed and built using ideas from cellular automata (CA). Calibrating such models to real situations is highly problematic and to date, serious attention has not been focused on the estimation problem. In this paper, we propose a structure for simulating urban change based on
Result.Title: Stochastic cellular automata modeling of urban land use dynamics: empirical development and estimation

Result.Abstract: In this paper, we propose a model of growth and form in which the processes of growth are intimately linked to the resulting geometry of the system. The model, first developed by Witten and Sander and referred to as the diffusion-limited aggregation or DLA model, generates highly ramified tree-like clusters of particles, or populations, with evident self-similarity about a fixed
Result.Title: Urban growth and form: scaling, fractal geometry, and diffusion-limited aggregation

Result.Abstract: We propose and test a model that describes the morphology of cities, the scaling of the urban perimeter of individual cities, and the area distribution of systems of cities. Result.Title: Modeling urban growth patterns with correlated percolation

Result.Abstract: A complex system is an entity, coherent in some recognisable way but whose elements, interactions, and dynamics generate structures and admit surprise and novelty that cannot be defined a priori. Complex systems are more than the sum of their parts, and a consequence of this is that any model of their structure is necessarily incomplete and partial. Models thus represent
Result.Title: Modelling and prediction in a complex world

Result.Abstract: New forms of representation at a fine spatial scale, in which units of space are conceived as cells and populations as individual agents, are currently changing the way we are able to simulate the evolution of cities. Result.Title: Agents, cells, and cities: new representational models for simulating multiscale urban dynamics

Result.Abstract: The space that can be seen from any vantage point is called an isovist and the set of such spaces forms a visual field whose extent defines different isovist fields based on different geometric properties. I suggest that our perceptions of moving within such fields might be related to these geometric properties. I begin with a formal representation of isovists
Result.Title: Exploring isovist fields: space and shape in architectural and urban morphology

Result.Abstract: In this paper, we argue that the geometry of urban residential development is fractal. Both the degree to which space is filled and the rate at which it is filled follow scaling laws which imply invariance of function, and self-similarity of urban form across scale. These characteristics are captured in population density functions based on inverse power laws whose parameters
Result.Title: Preliminary evidence for a theory of the fractal city

Result.Title: Rank clocks

Result.Title: Geometric accessibility and geographic information: extending desktop GIS to space syntax

Result.Title: The calibration of gravity, entropy, and related models of spatil interaction

Result.Title: The fractal simulation of urban structure

Result.Title: Morphology from imagery: detecting and measuring the density of urban land use

Result.Title: Simulating Emergent Urban Form Using Agent-Based Modeling: Desakota in the Suzhou-Wuxian Region in China

Result.Title: Modelling Inside GIS: Part 2. Selecting and Calibrating Urban Models Using ARC-INFO

Result.Title: Generating urban forms from diffusive growth

Result.Title: Urban Modelling

Result.Title: A New Theory of Space Syntax1

Result.Title: Urban modeling in computer-graphic and geographic information system environments

Result.Abstract: This paper is concerned with building up methodological guidelines for modelling urban land‐use change through Geographical Information Systems, remote sensing imagery and Bayesian probabilistic methods. Result.Title: GIS and remote sensing as tools for the simulation of urban land‐use change

Result.Title: THE IMPACT AND PENETRATION OF LOCATION-BASED SERVICES

Result.Title: The computable city

Result.Title: The morphology of urban land use

different definitions affect the statistical distribution of urban activity. A
commonly employed method of defining a metropolitan area is the Metropolitan

city as a functional economic region, and is constructed using experience. The

Result.Title: Laws of population growth

Result.Abstract: Space syntax is a technique for measuring the relative accessibility of different locations in a spatial system which has been loosely partitioned into convex spaces. These spaces are approximated by straight lines, called axial lines, and the topological graph associated with their intersection is used to generate indices of distance, called integration, which are then used as proxies for accessibility.
Result.Title: The automatic definition and generation of axial lines and axial maps

Result.Title: Do Green Belts Change the Shape of Urban Areas? A Preliminary Analysis of the Settlement Geography of South East England

Result.Title: Diffusion-limited aggregation and the fractal nature of urban growth

Result.Title: Fractal-based description of urban form

Result.Title: Agent-Based Pedestrian Modelling

Result.Title: Network Geography: Relations, Interactions, Scaling and Spatial Processes in GIS

Result.Title: Progress, success, and failure in urban modelling

Cities grow from hamlets and villages into small towns and thence into larger forms such as 'metropolis', 'megalopolis' and world cities which are 'gigalopolis'. Result.Title: Hierarchy in Cities and City Systems

Result.Title: Spatial aggregation in gravity models. 1. An information-theoretic framework

Result.Title: Reilly's challenge: new laws of retail gravitation which define systems of central places

Result.Abstract: Most attempts at building mathematical models of cities treat such systems as if they are in static equilibrium. Result.Title: Modelling Cities as Dynamic Systems

Result.Title: INTEGRATED URBAN EVOLUTIONARY MODELING

Result.Title: NeoGeography and Web 2.0: concepts, tools and applications

Result.Title: Building the virtual city: Public participation through e-democracy

Result.Title: Mapping for the Masses: Accessing Web 2.0 Through Crowdsourcing

Result.Title: Model cities

Result.Title: Spatial aggregation in gravity models: 4. Generalisations and large-scale applications

Result.Abstract: This paper seeks to extend the macrostatic approach to urban modelling by treating modelling problems as many-stage processes. Coleman (1964) calls this approach the 'method of residues', and
Result.Title: The method of residues in urban modelling

Result.Title: Distance in Space Syntax

Result.Title: RANK CLOCKS AND PLANT COMMUNITY DYNAMICS

We briefly review recent developments in methods for the automatic extraction of road centre line networks and propose a related algorithm aimed at encoding the geometry of road networks with line segments. Result.Title: Encoding geometric information in road networks extracted from binary images

Result.Title: Teaching spatial modelling using interacting computers and interactive computer graphics

Result.Title: Spatial aggregation in gravity models: 2. One-dimensional population density models

Result.Title: Spatial aggregation in gravity models: 3. Two-dimensional trip distribution and location models

Result.Abstract: This paper presents an exploration into the effect of symmetric structure on the equilibrium properties of a widely applied class of ergodic Markov processes. An initial discussion of the notions concerning structure and process in this context sets the scene for the statement and proof of a simple theorem relating structures with a symmetry property to their associated steady-state relationships.
Result.Title: Symmetric structure in spatial and social processes

Result.Abstract: This paper presents an approach to urban dynamics that generalizes the traditional rank-size model first popularized by Zipf (1949). Result.Title: THE EMERGENCE OF CITIES: COMPLEXITY AND URBAN DYNAMICS

Result.Title: The geography of scientific productivity: scaling in US computer science

Result.Title: Representing Multifunctional Cities: Density and Diversity in Space and Time
